descr.p: The syncobjs unit implements some classes which can be used when synchronizing threads in routines or classes that are used in multiple threads at once. The class is a wrapper around low-level critical section routines (semaphores or mutexes). The class can be used to send messages between threads (also known as conditional variables in POSIX threads).

element.name: PSecurityAttributes
element.descr: PSecurityAttributes is a dummy type used in non-windows implementations, so the calls remain Delphi compatible.

element.name: TEventHandle
element.descr: TEventHandle is an opaque type and should not be used in user code.

element.name: INFINITE
element.descr: Constant denoting an infinite timeout.

element.name: TWaitResult
element.descr: TWaitResult is used to report the result of a wait operation.

element.name: TWaitResult.wrError
element.short: An error occurred during the wait operation.

element.name: TSynchroObject
element.descr: TSynchroObject is an abstract synchronization resource object. It implements 2 virtual methods Acquire which can be used to acquire the resource, and Release to release the resource.

element.name: TSynchroObject.Acquire
element.descr: Acquire does nothing in TSynchroObject. Descendent classes must override this method to acquire the resource they manage.

element.name: TSynchroObject.Release
element.descr: Release does nothing in TSynchroObject. Descendent classes must override this method to release the resource they acquired through the Acquire call.

descr.p: TCriticalSection is a class wrapper around the low-level TRTLCriticalSection routines. It simply calls the RTL routines in the system unit for critical section support.

A critical section is a resource which can be owned by only 1 caller: it can be used to make sure that in a multithreaded application only 1 thread enters pieces of code protected by the critical section.
Typical usage is to protect a piece of code with the following code (MySection is a TCriticalSection instance):
The protected code can be executed by only 1 thread at a time. This is useful for instance for list operations in multithreaded environments.

element.name: TCriticalSection.Acquire
element.descr: Acquire attempts to enter the critical section. It will suspend the calling thread if the critical section is in use by another thread, and will resume as soon as the other thread has released the critical section.

element.name: TCriticalSection.Release
element.descr: Release leaves the critical section. It will free the critical section so another thread waiting to enter the critical section will be awakened, and will enter the critical section. This call always returns immediately.

element.name: TCriticalSection.Enter
element.descr: Enter just calls Acquire.

element.name: TCriticalSection.Leave
element.descr: Leave just calls Release

element.name: TCriticalSection.Create
element.descr: Create initializes a new critical section, and initializes the system objects for the critical section. It should be created only once for all threads, all threads should use the same critical section instance.

element.name: TCriticalSection.Destroy

descr.p: Destroy releases the system critical section resources, and removes the TCriticalSection instance from memory.

element.errors: Any threads trying to enter the critical section when it is destroyed, will start running with an error (an exception should be raised).

element.name: THandleObject
element.short: Class encapsulating an operating system handle
element.descr: THandleObject is a parent class for synchronization classes that need to store an operating system handle. It introduces a property Handle which can be used to store the operating system handle. The handle is in no way manipulated by THandleObject, only storage is provided.

element.name: THandleObject.destroy
element.descr: Destroy does nothing in the Free Pascal implementation of THandleObject.

element.name: THandleObject.Handle
element.descr: Handle provides read-only access to the operating system handle of this instance. The public access is read-only, descendent classes should set the handle by accessing it's protected field FHandle directly.

element.name: THandleObject.LastError
element.descr: LastError provides read-only access to the last operating system error code for operations on Handle.

element.name: TEventObject
element.descr: TEventObject encapsulates the BasicEvent implementation of the system unit in a class. The event can be used to notify other threads of a change in conditions. (in POSIX terms, this is a conditional variable). A thread that wishes to notify other threads creates an instance of TEventObject with a certain name, and posts events to it. Other threads that wish to be notified of these events should create their own instances of TEventObject with the same name, and wait for events to arrive.

descr.p: Create creates a new event object with unique name AName. The object will be created with security attributes EventAttributes (this parameters is used on Windows only).

The AManualReset indicates whether the event must be reset manually (if it is False, the event is reset immediately after the first thread waiting for it is notified). InitialState determines whether the event is initially set or not.

element.name: TEventObject.Create.Name
element.short: Name uniquely identifying the event in this process.

element.name: TEventObject.destroy
element.short: Clean up the event and release from memory
element.descr: Destroy cleans up the low-level resources allocated for this event and releases the event instance from memory.

element.name: TEventObject.ResetEvent
element.descr: ResetEvent turns off the event. Any WaitFor operation will suspend the calling thread.

element.name: TEventObject.SetEvent
element.descr: SetEvent sets the event. If the ManualReset is True any thread that was waiting for the event to be set (using WaitFor) will resume it's operation. After the event was set, any thread that executes WaitFor will return at once. If ManualReset is False, only one thread will be notified that the event was set, and the event will be immediately reset after that.

element.name: TEventObject.WaitFor
element.short: Wait for the event to be set.

descr.p: WaitFor should be used in threads that should be notified when the event is set. When WaitFor is called, and the event is not set, the thread will be suspended. As soon as the event is set by some other thread (using SetEvent) or the timeout period (TimeOut) has expired, the WaitFor function returns. The return value depends on the condition that caused the WaitFor function to return.
The calling thread will wait indefinitely when the constant INFINITE is specified for the TimeOut parameter.

element.name: TEventObject.WaitFor.Timeout
element.short: Maximum time to wait for the event to be set

element.name: TEventObject.ManualReset
element.short: Should the event be reset manually
element.descr: ManualReset indicates whether the event must be reset manually: if it is False, the event is reset immediately after the first thread waiting for it is notified. if it is True, then the event is never reset automatically, and ResetEvent must be called manually after a thread was notified.

element.name: TEvent
element.descr: TEvent is a simple alias for the class.

element.name: TSimpleEvent
element.descr: TSimpleEvent is a simple descendent of the class. It creates an event with no name, which must be reset manually, and which is initially not set.

element.name: TSimpleEvent.Create
element.descr: Create instantiates a new TSimpleEvent instance. It simply calls the inherited Create with Nil for the security attributes, an empty name, AManualReset set to True, and InitialState to False.

element.name: TCriticalSection.TryEnter
element.short: Try and obtain the critical section
element.descr: TryEnter tries to enter the critical section: it returns at once and does not wait if the critical section is owned by another thread; if the current thread owns the critical section or the critical section was obtained successfully, true is returned. If the critical section is currently owned by another thread, False is returned.

element.name: TCriticalSection.TryEnter.Result
element.short: False if another thread owns the critical section, true if obtained at once.

element.name: ESyncObjectException
element.short: Exception object used in unit syncobjs
element.descr: ESyncObjectException is used in the constructor of to indicate failure to create a basic event.

element.name: ELockException
element.descr: ELockException is provided for Delphi compatibility. It is not used in FPC.

element.name: ELockRecursionException
element.descr: ELockRecursionException is provided for Delphi compatibility. It is not used in FPC.
